title: Say Less, Mean More: Leveraging Pragmatics in Retrieval-Augmented Generation
author: Haris Riaz (University of Arizona), Ellen Riloff (University of Arizona), Mihai Surdeanu (University of Arizona), ...
relevance_why: The paper discusses pragmatics applied to Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), potentially applicable to audio-text generation tasks where accurate retrieval is essential.
background: Enhancing question-answering systems using language models by reducing irrelevant information during retrieval processes to improve performance.
contribution: This paper introduces a method to incorporate pragmatic principles into Retrieval-Augmented Generation frameworks to enhance the relevance and clarity of retrieved information.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing RAG methods often provide excessive information that can confuse models due to irrelevance.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves retrieval by focusing on highlighting relevant sentences without truncating context, thereby respecting communication principles.

key_innovation: The method dynamically highlights the most relevant evidence sentences based on semantic alignment to improve clarity and utility in knowledge retrieval.
real_world_impact: This approach can enhance various applications like automated question answering, providing more straightforward answers and improving user experience in conversational AI systems.
limitations: The approach struggles with queries needing arithmetic reasoning or contextual negation and relies on previously retrieved sentences, which may introduce noise.

new_terms.pragmatics: **Pragmatics** refers to the study of how context influences the interpretation of meaning in communication.
new_terms.Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG): A framework that combines pre-trained models with external data retrieval to enhance model outputs, thereby extending the model's knowledge base.
